qas.question: What is the government of India based on?

answers.text: the Constitution of India delineates the subjects on which each tier of government has executive powers

qas.question: What was the constitution originally provided for?
When the third tiere was added on, what is it in form of?
What isn't the government of India based on?

plausible_answers.text: the Constitution of India delineates the subjects on which each tier of government has executive powers

qas.question: What was the constitution originally not provided for?
What was the constitution never provided for?
When the third tiere was taken off, what is it in form of?

context: The government of India is based on a <a0_0><b4_0>tiered system<b4_0/><a0_0/>, in which <a1_0><b5_0>the Constitution of India delineates the subjects on which each tier of government has executive powers<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The Constitution originally provided for a <a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>two-tier system of government<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>, the Union Government (also known as the Central Government), representing the Union of India, and the State governments. Later, a third tier was added in the form of <a3_0><b8_0>Panchayats and Municipalities<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In the current arrangement, The Seventh Schedule of the Indian Constitution delimits the subjects of each level of governmental jurisdiction, dividing them into three lists:
